habitat_description:
Southwest:
This subspecies of Microtus californicus is isolated to bulrush marshes along the Amargosa River near Tecopa/Tecopa Hot Springs in southeastern Inyo County, CA. It was listed endangered by USFWS in 1984 (49 FR 45160–15164) due to the geographically restricted nature of its range, destruction of small amounts of remaining wetland habitat, and severly limited population size (USFWS 1997). Habitat requirements include isolated, riparian and wetland vegetation dominated by an overstory of bulrush (Scirpus olneyi) and cattails (Typha spp.) in narrow swaths along the Amargosa River (USFWS 1997, McClenaghan and Montgomery 1998). Understory vegetation includes yerba mansa (Anemopsis californica) and saltgrass (Distichlis spicata) (USFWS 2009). "The notable difference between vole presence and absence within similar habitats is the vulnerability of an area to flooding. Only habitat above 1,370 feet (410 meters) in elevation remains secure for the vole during extreme flooding and highwater (what is locally called the “30 year floods”) (Murphy and Freas 1989)"(quoted directly from USFWS 1997).
